 SUMMARY AND CONCLUSION This paper uses data from the National Socioeconomic Survey for 1978 (SUSENAS 1978) to give a profile of poverty in Indonesia. Households are classified into the poor, better-off and rich categories according to their levels of per capita consumption, with a breakdown into urban and rural areas of Java and the Outer Islands. Defining "the poor" as the two lowest quintiles of the distribution of the population ranked by their households' levels of per capita consumption, the overall urban incidence of poverty is 14% compared with 42% for rural households. For each of the areas, the incidence of poverty is considerably lower in the Outer Islands than in Java. Different categories of households are then compared in terms of their characteristics; these can be divided into those associated with the causes and those associated with the consequences of poverty. Of the factors associated with the causes of poverty, the paper shows that the poor have larger families and also a larger number of members in the labor force. However, each member of the labor force in a poor household has more dependents to support on average than one from a better-off or rich household. The heads of poor households have less education, as do their household members. Education level has a direct bearing on the probability that a household is poor; the incidence of poor households is inversely related to the level of educational attainment of the household head. Members of poor households change jobs frequently and more of those already working are prepared to accept additional jobs, while more of those who are not working would be willing to accept a job if available. The poor are more likely to be looking for work than those who are not poor, especially
 - 2 - in urban areas. The poor are more likely to have agriculture as their main source of income than others. In rural areas, households are more likely to be engaged in nonagricultural activities if the size of their landholding is inadequate when compared to their household size. Among households for whom agriculture is the main source of income, a smaller proportion of poor households work on their own land compared with other households. Thus control over land can be linked to the income levels of households. Of the factors associated with the consequences of poverty, the poor are found to spend a much larger share of their total budget on food and correspondingly smaller shares on other categories of consumption, such as expenditures related to schooling and health. Within the food category, they spend the greater part of the budget on carbohydrates, namely rice, cassava and their byproducts, and relatively much smaller shares for sources of protein like fish, meat and eggs. Thus the nutritional content of foods consumed by the poor and those who are not is quite dissimilar. The paper documents the inferior living conditions of the poor in their housing structure and amenities, such as the availability of water and electricity. In social services, a smaller proportion of the children of the poor attend school beyond the primary level. The poor do not receive health care of as good a quality as the other groups: they are less likely to use physicians and more likely to rely on less-qualified health personnel, such as folk doctors. Related work deals with some of the individual topics in this paper in greater detail, with a view of reaching a better understanding of the causes and consequences of poverty in Indonesia.

 Introduction The purpose of this paper is to give a brief description of households in Indonesia with a view of comparing and contrasting poor and nonpoor households. It is meant to be a snapshot, capturing at a given point in time different aspects of what households do and how they live, thereby providing a background for further analytical work to be treated in several subsequent papers. The paper relies on the data tapes of the National Socioeconomic Survey conducted by the Central Bureau of Statistics in 1978 (SUSENAS 1978). The survey was conducted in four rounds, with over 6,000 households interviewed in each of the rounds. The data in this paper come from the second round of the survey which was conducted in May 1978. The sections which follow deal in turn with the geographical distribution of poverty; demographic aspects of poverty; economic and non- economic activities of individuals; sources of household income; consumption patterns; housing conditions; and schooling and health. The emphasis will be on differences between poor and nonpoor households throughout.
 - 2- I. Geographical Distribution In this section we begin the profile of poverty in Indonesia by describing where the poor are located geographically. We do not attempt to define objectively a poverty line for Indonesia since we feel that such a line, however carefully defined, necessarily incorporates many arbitrary assumptions. For purposes of comparing different groups of the population, we classify households into three groups according to their levels of per capita consumption expenditures. In this paper, "the poor" will refer to the two lowest quintiles (or 40%) of the distribution of the population ranked by their household's level of per capita consumption expenditure; "the better- off" will refer to the next two quintiles; and "the rich" will refer to the top quintile (or 20%). A household or an individual is said to be in poverty" if it or he belongs to the "poor" group. Table 1.1 gives the incidence of poverty, the proportion of households classified as poor, that is, those belonging to the lower 40% of the per capita expenditure distribution, for urban and rural areas of Java and the Outer Islands. The figures show that, by this definition, the overall urban incidence of poverty is 14% compared with 42% for rural households; the urban-rural difference holds for Java and the Outer Islands separately as well. For each of the areas, the incidence of poverty is considerably lower in the Outer Islands than in Java. Since rural Java has a higher incidence of poverty than Indonesia as a whole, it has more than its share of the poor and less of the rich; rural Java contains 55% of all households but 77% of poor households and only 25% of rich households. The three remaining areas have less than their share of the poor and more of the rich. Thus, with a share of 11% of all households, urban Java has 5Z of the poor households, and 25% of the rich households.

Demographic Characteristics II.1 Household Size, Number of Adults and Dependency Ratios Studies of income distribution have found that poor households tend to be larger than better-off ones when a household is classified as being poor or not on the basis of its level of per capita income or consumption expenditures. Moreover, this result is robust with respect to the standardization for household size; when the classification of households is based on income or consumption per adult-equivalent, the poorer households tend to be larger as well. It follows then that the incidence of poverty for people is higher than for households. Moreover, larger households usually have more children, as well as a larger proportion of children in the total. Hence the incidence of poverty falls more heavily on children than it does on adults. Indonesia is no exception. In Table 2.1 we give the proportion of poor households, those whose members belong to the two lowest quintiles of the per capita consumption expenditure distribution. As expected, the proportion of the population who are poor is higher than that for households, showing that poorer households are indeed larger than better-off ones. In addition, the incidence of poverty among children under ten years of age is significantly higher than that for the population as a whole; thus poorer households are also ones with more children.

II.2 Poverty and Characteristics of the Household Head In addition to the demographic characteristics of households, we compare poor and nonpoor households in terms of some of the characteristics of their household heads: sex, marital status, age and level of educational attainment. Table 2.3 gives the distribution of households by the sex, marital status, age group and level of educational attainment of the household head, as well as the proportion of households in each category which are poor. In rural Java, 20% of households are headed by women, compared with 14% in urban Java. The proportion of poor households among female-headed households is lower in rural Java than among those headed by men, however. In urban areas, as well as rural areas of the Outer Islands, households headed by women are more likely to be poor than ones headed by men. When we classify households by the marital status of the household head as well as sex, we see that most of the male heads are married. In contrast, the female heads are mostly widowed or divorced, although a number of them are single or married. The proportion of household heads who are single is higher in urban than in rural areas for both males and females in both Java and the Outer Islands. For female-headed households, the incidence of poverty is typically higher when the head is widowed or divorced than when she is single or married.

 - 12 - III. Economic and Noneconomic Activities In this section we look at the activities of individuals in poor, better-off and rich households. We then focus in turn on the working population, those looking for work and those engaged solely in nonmarket activities. I11.1 Activities of Individuals Table 3.1 is an attempt to classify all individuals aged ten and over according to their activities over a one-week period. Because the SUSENAS 1978 questionnaire recorded what individuals did on different days, we are able to gain some insight into their mix of activities during the week preceding the survey. We classify the activities into three major categories: being employed, looking for work, and doing nonmarket work. The category employed includes working, and having a job but being away from work; the category doing nonmarket work includes attending school, taking care of the house, and doing other nonmarket activities. Some people can be neatly classified into one of these three categories: employed (working and/or away from work); looking for work; and doing nonmarket work (attending school and/or taking care of the house and/or doing other nonmarket work). A certain proportion of individuals, however, performed more than one activity. For example, 9% of the urban poor in Java did nonmarket activities in addition to working. Survey questions which force individuals to be classified into only one category would miss the fact that many people in fact do not fall clearly into just one category.  - 55 - Summary and Conclusion This paper uses data from the National Socio-economic Survey for 1978 (SUSENAS 1978) to give a profile of poverty in Indonesia. Households are classified into the poor, better-off and rich categories according to their levels of per capita consumption, with a breakdown into urban and rural areas of Java and the Outer Islands. Poor, better-off and rich households are then compared in terms of their characteristics; these can be divided into those associated with the causes and those associated with the consequences of poverty. With regard to factors associated with the causes of poverty, the paper shows that the poor are at a disadvantage from a demographic standpoint: they have larger families and, more importantly, relatively more children and hence higher dependency ratios. Their heads of households have less education, as do their households members. More of their members are in the labor force and they work longer hours. Yet they change jobs more frequently and more of those already working are prepared to accept additional jobs while more of those who are not working are willing to accept a suitable job. The poor are more likely to rely on agriculture as their main source of income. In rural areas, households are more likely to be engaged in nonagricultural activities the less adequate is the size of their landholding given their household size. With respect to factors associated with the consequences of poverty, the poor are found to spend a much larger share of their total budget on food and correspondingly smaller shares on other categories of consumption. Within the food category they spend the greater part of the budget on carbohydrates, namely paddy, cassava and their byproducts.
 - 56 - The living conditions of the poor are clearly inferior in terms of their housing structure and amenities, such as availability of water and electricity. The poor are less likely to own radios and televisions or to receive newspapers and magazines on a regular basis. A smaller proportion of the children of the poor attend school beyond the lower primary level. The poor do not receive health care of as good a quality as the nonpoor: they are less likely to use physicians and rely more on less-qualified health personnel, such as folk doctors. We thus find that great differences can be found in the way that the poor and the nonpoor live. There are factors which suggest why the poor do not attain levels of income which are as high as the nonpoor. There are also clear manifestations on the consumption side of what it means to be poor. The paper is intended to serve merely as a descriptive backdrop of the lives of Indonesians whom we are studying. Subsequent work will deal with the individual topics in this paper in greater detail, with a view of reaching a better understanding of the causes and consequences of poverty in Indonesia.

doc.abstracts: Data from the National Socio-economic Survey for 1978 are used to give a profile of poverty in Indonesia. Households are classified into the poor and nonpoor categories according to their levels of per capita consumption, with a breakdown into urban and rural areas of Java and the Outer Islands. Poor and nonpoor households are then compared in terms of their geographical distribution, demographic characteristics, economic and noneconomic activities of individuals, sources of household income, consumption patterns, housing conditions, and schooling and health.
